fable:
On the rugged cliff-top fortress, a curious and clever koala lived. She spent each day exploring the nooks and crannies, finding tasty leaves for her family to eat. But no matter how hard she tried, her big sister, a proud and confident koala, always seemed to get the praise.

"Wow, look at how many leaves you found, big sister," said the other koalas. "You're the best forager!" But when the clever koala tried to share her ideas, her sister would interrupt and say, "No, no, that's not a good idea. I know what's best."

The clever koala felt sad and alone. She wondered if she was just not good enough. One day, while out on a walk, she stumbled upon a hidden patch of juicy berries. She knew just what to do and gathered as many as she could. But when she returned to the fortress, her sister swooped in and took all the credit.

The clever koala felt so frustrated that she decided to gather all the koalas together and ask for their help. "Friends, I have an idea," she said. "Let's all vote on who deserves the praise. That way, it will be fair." The koalas agreed and held a vote. To everyone's surprise, the clever koala won for her clever berry-gathering idea.

The koalas cheered and hugged her. The proud sister looked on, feeling ashamed. "I'm sorry I didn't listen to you before," she said. "You're clever and I'm proud of you!" From that day on, the clever koala and her sister worked together, and the fortress was filled with laughter and friendship. The clever koala learned that second chances can reveal new paths and that working together is always the best idea.

In the big, old warehouse, a Prudent Leopard loved to play hide-and-seek with her friends. One sunny day, she found a shiny, new collar with sparkly stones in the dusty corner. She put it on and said, "Wow! This makes me the most beautiful leopard in the world!"

Her friends, a Clever Monkey and a Swift Rabbit, were impressed by the collar. "Wow, you look amazing!" they said. The Prudent Leopard thought, "If I keep this collar, they will like me even more." So, she didn't tell them that it wasn't hers.

But soon, the Prudent Leopard started to feel bad. She was worried that someone would see the collar and think she stole it. She tried to play with her friends, but they kept staring at her collar and saying, "Look at you! You're so fancy!"

The Prudent Leopard's feelings hurt, and she said, "I don't want to play anymore." Her friends asked, "What's wrong?" She explained, "I feel bad because I don't own this collar. I was wrong to keep it."

The Clever Monkey and the Swift Rabbit looked at each other and said, "We like you just the way you are, without the collar!" The Prudent Leopard felt happy and said, "Thank you for understanding. I promise to always tell the truth from now on."

From that day on, the Prudent Leopard's friends respected her even more. They learned that honesty invites respect, and the Prudent Leopard learned to always be truthful, no matter what.

**The Wise Owl and the Secret Garden**

In a sunny countryside, a disciplined owl perched high on a tree branch. She watched over the fields and forests, keeping all the creatures safe. One day, she discovered a hidden garden filled with juicy berries and sweet honey. The owl was thrilled to share this secret with her friends, a rabbit, a squirrel, and a hedgehog. Together, they promised to protect the garden and take turns caring for it.

But, one morning, the owl woke up to find the garden ruined. The rabbit, the squirrel, and the hedgehog were all standing nearby, looking guilty. "What happened?" the owl asked. They confessed: they had worked together to destroy the garden, thinking it was all their own secret.

The owl was heartbroken. "Why did you do this?" she asked. The rabbit explained, "We thought it was too much work to share." The owl realized that her friends didn't understand the value of teamwork and sharing.

The owl came up with a plan. "Let's work together to rebuild the garden! We can learn from each other and make it even better." The friends agreed and got to work. As they planted new flowers and harvested berries, they discovered that sharing their knowledge and skills made their task easier and more fun.

The garden flourished, and the friends celebrated their hard work. "We're stronger together," said the rabbit. "Sharing our knowledge made all the difference," added the owl. From that day on, the friends continued to work together, learning from each other and growing their friendship. The moral of the story is: sharing knowledge empowers all.

fable:
The crumbling monastery stood atop a hill, its stones worn by time and wind. A stubborn camel with a hump as big as a boulder roamed the crumbling grounds, refusing to leave.

One day, a wise old tortoise with a shell as hard as stone and eyes as bright as the sun approached the camel. "Why do you stay here?" the tortoise asked gently. "The monastery is crumbling, and it's not safe."

The camel snorted, "I can handle it. I'm strong and can carry heavy loads."

But the tortoise showed the camel how the walls were cracking, and the roof was about to fall in. "Even the strongest can use help," the tortoise said patiently.

The camel refused to listen, insisting on carrying the weight alone. But as the days passed, the camel struggled more and more. The walls creaked, and the roof groaned.

Just when the camel thought it couldn't go on, a group of friendly monkeys arrived, each with a tool in hand. Together, they helped the camel repair the monastery. The camel learned to accept help and worked alongside the monkeys.

When the monastery was fixed, the monkeys shared their knowledge with the camel, teaching it how to reinforce the walls and fix the roof. The camel was amazed at how much stronger it felt, knowing that it had learned something new.

The tortoise smiled, "Sharing knowledge is like sharing a basket of fresh fruits. Everyone gets a piece, and everyone benefits." The camel nodded in agreement, grateful for the lesson it had learned. From that day on, the camel was no longer stubborn, and the monastery stood strong once more.
